p: The genus Gentiana comprises about 400 species primarily distributed throughout the Eurasian mountainous regions, while some species are found in lowlands and some are distributed in diverse habitats in the Andes, India, New Zealand, and Southern Australia [ 1]. Most gentian species are valued as medicinal and ornamental plants and are intensively researched due to the presence of pharmacologically important phytochemicals. Gentians are prescribed by many traditional pharmacopoeias and incorporated into more than a hundred official drugs, owing to their most important active constituents, secoiridoid glycosides and xanthones [ 2].
